subtitle: Hello and welcome, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I’d like to explore with you a Brazilian
spiritist vision of the afterlife. To do so, let me set the stage a little bit because,
for many of you who have not travelled to Brazil, you may not realize how vital
Spiritism is in Brazilian culture. Now, when I say Spiritism,
I am referring very specifically to a
style of belief based on the writings of the French
pedagogue who wrote under the pen name of Allan Kardec.
He wrote 5 or 6 books which are regarded as the Bible of
Spiritism. Now, he used a very systematic
method in developing these books, because, as I said, he was a pedagogue, a scholar. He would
interview various spiritualist mediums of
the time in France and ask them questions about the afterlife. When they agreed, when he could find
correlation from several different mediumistic sources, he took that to be
evidential. He wrote his books about the description of the afterlife,
5 or 6 books, The Book of Spirits, many others,
based on his evaluation of the
testimony from these spiritualist mediums. Now, he founded a movement known as Spiritism.
It it was something of a rage in Paris and in Europe in the 19th century
but where it really seems to have taken root is in Brazil. The Brazillian culture
mixed Kardecian Spiritism with some of the native
traditions, particularly the African
traditions that were brought to Brazil by African slaves. So, you have
a combination of religions in Brazil that
involve the African traditions and the European Spiritist traditions and various amalgamations
amongst them, Umbanda,
Candomble, and of course, pure Spiritism.
Now, amongst the most famous Spiritist mediums in Brazil was Chico Xavier.
He died in
2002. He was born in 1910, so he lived to 92 years old. He would go into trance and
write books. He was really a relatively uneducated person, of peasant stock,
but he actually authored some over
400 books in his lifetime. He claimed, of course, that these were books
dictated to him by spirits on the other side, including some well known writers.
In fact, in one case, as I recall, the widow of one of these writers sued Chico
Xavier and tried to collect the royalties on
the book, claiming that if her husband, her deceased husband, wrote the books,
she was entitled to the royalties, not him.
I don't think she prevailed in court.
But, he’s so famous throughout Brazil that postage stamps were issued in his name. Furthermore,
the revenues-- his books sold, I understand, over 50 million copies in
Brazil-- and he used the revenues
all for charitable purposes, which would be totally consistent with the
values of Brazilian Spiritism. In fact, a great deal of the charity work in Brazil, even though
it's nominally a Catholic nation, is actually conducted by the Spiritists.
The Spiritist community in Brazil is indeed very bright, very vibrant.
Now, I’d like to talk about a particular
film that was made based on one of the books written by Chico Xavier. The
Brazilian name for the film is Nosso Lar, which means “Our Home.”
There is an English version of the film available called Astral City. It's about life in
a city, a Brazilian city on the astral plane, a city inhabited
by the spirits of the deceased.
The film is supposedly,
or the novel upon which the film was based,
it doesn't claim to be a novel, it claims to be a
firsthand account written by a Spirit on the other side of his journey.
Nobody has really
come up with an identification of the real person, at least not a satisfactory identification. There has been
actually a great deal of speculation. But, in the
treatment, the book written by Chico Javier,
dictated to Chico Javier, the author is a physician who calls himself Andre Luis.
You see him in the movie dying of a heart attack, or something like that.
You know, he's having dinner with his wife and he just keels over. He’s dead,
they can't revive him and then he finds himself in a very strange,
haunting, forbidden, dark place. It's
really very unpleasant as the movie opens.
One gets the sense that this
doctor is not in heaven. Maybe he was a selfish man in his lifetime. As the story progresses,
we do get that impression. Not a spiritually evolved person at all, but a good doctor.
He spends some time in this place of
darkness and strange, mad people, and
forbidding landscapes. Finally, he’s just had enough and he prays, “Oh God, help me, help me!”
That's when the
rescuers come from the astral city of Nosso Lar to
find him. They bring him back into their city through a great wall and
into something like an infirmary, a hospital where he is able to recover.
He wakes up in the hospital. He says, “Where am I? What happened? Who are you? What's going on here?”
Gradually, as the movie unfolds, he learns that he’s in the astral city.
One of the people who treated him in the astral hospital becomes his monitor and guide and
introduces him to the
city itself. He wants desperately to return to see his wife and family
but that is not allowed. He has many, many questions and
gradually they are answered. Bit by bit he becomes, one might say, a better person.
He comes to work in the hospital. It's not like medical, it's more like a place of spiritual healing.
He becomes sensitized to the ways of spiritual healing through his work in the hospital.
Gradually, he’s
given permission to meet with some of the higher-up authorities in this city and learns how it's
operating. He’s even
gifted with a visit from his mother. Now, his mother has
evolved to an even higher
spiritual plane, so it’s like, he cannot visit her because he can't yet enter into her plane.
But, she can come to the city of Nosso Lar and visit him, and she does.
He learns as well that the other people there have issues that they are still working on. His good friend,
Lisias, the one who
helps him initially in the hospital, introduces him to his family.
Then Lisias learns that his mother, who is
living with him in Nosso Lar, is about to be reborn on Earth again.
And he’s missing her terribly. He doesn't want her to go,
and he's attached. So, a good part of the lessons for the people here is: let go of attachments.
Love the people you love but let them move on. In fact, Andre Luis at one point
in the story is given permission, finally, near the end to visit his wife and family.
He sees that they’ve moved on. In fact, his wife is remarried.
He sees his wife in bed with another man. At first
he’s very troubled by this. But eventually he sees, wait, this other man is sick, this other man
also needs healing. And he, invisible as he is at the time because he’s something like a ghost,
channels healing to his wife’s --
ex-wife, I guess you’d have to say -- her new husband. In so doing, he achieves a new level of detachment
himself. So, his spiritual evolution is about
letting go of attachments,
being able to experience pure love without attachments, and then moving on.
Now, the book was originally published, as I recall, in
1944. So there's a sequence in the movie about The Great War and how
many people are going to die. And this astral city is going to be flooded with the
spirits of people who have died in the war. I'm not aware that Brazil was particularly involved,
but that’s the sequence of the movie. And you see, in this picture I’m showing you now, the
residents of Nosso Lar are reaching out.
They're going outside the big wall of their city to help bring back
the people who have passed away in the war and welcome them to this astral city.
You get the sense from the Spiritualist and Spiritist
literature that such places actually
exist in each country,
places where people can live a kind of life
on the astral plane that is similar to the life they led on Earth but different in some ways as
well, because the main focus does seem to be upon a
kind of spiritual evolution while you are there.
It reminds me to some extent of the
Hermetic saying
from the Emerald Tablets,
supposedly going back to ancient Egypt, “As above, so below,”
which suggests that
life on the astral plane is very much like life here on Earth.
Naturally, there will be some differences but the parallels will be quite striking. That is a very
graphic impression given by this
Brazilian Spiritist vision of things. Of course, the art of movie making makes it very concrete. You see
buildings, actually you see
electric conveyances like trains that move people around the city. There are parks, there are lakes,
there are houses, and, as I mentioned a hospital, and other forms of activity
not all that different from life here on Earth.
Well, some have suggested that what we experience in the
afterlife is often dependent upon our
attitudes, what we expect, what we have been conditioned to believe.
So, it would seem logical, in a sense.
I certainly can't endorse this movie as being an accurate description.
I don't know enough yet.
But, I have to say that I think the Spiritists and the Spiritualist literature deserves to be taken
seriously. It's certainly a very graphic and
detailed account of what the afterlife might well be like. I
guess the interesting
question for you at this point is, what sort of an afterlife, if any, would you like to experience?
If you could choose, if you could create
through the power of your imagination,
the power of your will, an afterlife that would be suited to you,
one that would provide you with
opportunities for growth and advancement on various
planes of existence, particularly
psychologically and spiritually, what would that look like for you?
Give that some thought. Thank you for being with me.
